The syndicate coordinates public transport and contracts it out to the RATP (operating 347 bus lines, the Métro, eight tramway lines, and sections of the RER), the SNCF (operating suburban rails, one tramway line and the other sections of the RER) and the Optile consortium of private operators managing 1,176 bus lines.According to a 2018 INSEE survey, a majority of <this city>ians (64.3 percent) use public transport to get to work. Only 10.6 percent commuted to work by automobile. 10.5 percent walked or used roller skates; 5.5 percent commuted by bicycle; and 4.4 percent commuted by motorbike. Bike lanes are being doubled, while electric car incentives are being created. The French capital is banning the most polluting automobiles from key districts.

Railways
A central hub of the national rail network, <this city>'s six major railway stations (Gare du Nord, Gare de l'Est, Gare de Lyon, Gare d'Austerlitz, Gare Montparnasse, Gare Saint-Lazare) and a minor one (Gare de Bercy) are connected to three networks: high-speed rail lines (TGV, Eurostar, Thalys, Intercity Express, Frecciarossa), normal speed trains (Intercités, Intercités de nuit, TER), and the suburban rails (Transilien). The Transilien is the commuter rail network serving <this city> region through 8 lines, 392 stations and 1,294 km (804.1 mi) of rails.
Since the inauguration of its first line in 1900, <this city>'s Métro network has grown to become the city's most widely used local transport system; today it carries about 5.23 million passengers daily through 16 lines, 308 stations (391 stops) and 226.9 km (141.0 mi) of rails. Superimposed on this is a 'regional express network', the RER, whose five lines, 257 stops and 587 km (365 mi) of rails connect <this city> to more distant parts of the urban area. In addition, the <this city> region is served by a light rail network, the tramway. Opened since 1992 for its first line, thirteen lines are currently operational. The network is 164.4 kilometres (102.2 mi) long with 248 stations.

Air
<this city> is a major international air transport hub with the 5th busiest airport system in the world. The city is served by three commercial international airports: Charles de Gaulle Airport, Orly Airport and Beauvais–Tillé Airport. Together these three airports recorded traffic of 112 million passengers in 2019. There is also one general aviation airport, <this city>–Le Bourget Airport, historically the oldest <this city>ian airport and closest to the city centre, which is now used only for private business flights and air shows. Charles de Gaulle Airport, located on the edge of the northern suburbs of <this city>, opened to commercial traffic in 1974 and became the busiest <this city>ian airport in 1993. For 2017 it was the 5th busiest airport in the world by international traffic and it is the hub for the nation's flag carrier Air <this country>. Beauvais-Tillé Airport, located 69 km (43 mi) north of <this city>'s city centre, is used by charter airlines and low-cost carriers.

Motorways
The city is also the most important hub of <this country>'s motorway network, and is surrounded by three orbital freeways: the Périphérique, which follows the approximate path of 19th-century fortifications around <this city>, the A86 motorway in the inner suburbs, and finally the Francilienne motorway in the outer suburbs. <this city> has an extensive road network with over 2,000 km (1,243 mi) of highways and motorways.

Waterways
The <this city> region is the most active water transport area in <this country>, with most of the cargo handled by Ports of <this city> in facilities located around <this city>. The rivers Loire, Rhine, Rhône, Meuse, and Scheldt can be reached by canals connecting with the Seine, which include the Canal Saint-Martin, Canal Saint-Denis, and the Canal de l'Ourcq.

Cycling
There are 440 km (270 mi) of cycle paths and routes in <this city>. These include piste cyclable (bike lanes separated from other traffic by physical barriers) and bande cyclable (a bicycle lane denoted by a painted path on the road). Some 29 km (18 mi) of specially marked bus lanes are free to be used by cyclists, with a protective barrier protecting against encroachments from vehicles. Cyclists have also been given the right to ride in both directions on certain one-way streets. <this city> offers a bike sharing system called Vélib' with more than 20,000 public bicycles distributed at 1,800 parking stations.

Electricity
Electricity is provided to <this city> through a peripheral grid fed by multiple sources. In 2012, around 50% of electricity generated in the Île-de-<this country> came from cogeneration energy plants; other energy sources included thermal power (35%), waste incineration (9% – with cogeneration plants, these provide the city in heat as well), methane gas (5%), hydraulics (1%), solar power (0.1%) and a negligible amount of wind power. A quarter of the city's district heating is to come from a plant in Saint-Ouen-sur-Seine, burning a 50/50-mix of coal and wood pellets.

Water and sanitation
<this city> in its early history had only the rivers Seine and Bièvre for water. From 1809, the Canal de l'Ourcq provided <this city> with water from less-polluted rivers to the north-east of the capital. From 1857, the civil engineer Eugène Belgrand, under Napoleon III, oversaw the construction of a series of new aqueducts that brought water from locations all around the city to several reservoirs. From then on, the new reservoir system became <this city>'s principal source of drinking water, and the remains of the old system, pumped into lower levels of the same reservoirs, were from then on used for the cleaning of <this city>'s streets. This system is still a major part of <this city>'s water-supply network. Today <this city> has more than 2,400 km (1,491 mi) of underground sewers.Air pollution in <this city>, from the point of view of particulate matter (PM10), is the highest in <this country> with 38 μg/m3. From the point of view of nitrogen dioxide pollution, <this city> has one of the highest levels in the EU.

Parks and gardens
<this city> today has more than 421 municipal parks and gardens, covering more than 3,000 hectares and containing more than 250,000 trees. Two of <this city>'s oldest and most famous gardens are the Tuileries Garden (created in 1564 for the Tuileries Palace and redone by André Le Nôtre between 1664 and 1672) and the Luxembourg Garden, for the Luxembourg Palace, built for Marie de' Medici in 1612, which today houses the Senate. The Jardin des plantes was the first botanical garden in <this city>, created in 1626.Between 1853 and 1870, Emperor Napoleon III and the city's first director of parks and gardens, Jean-Charles Adolphe Alphand, created the Bois de Boulogne, Bois de Vincennes, Parc Montsouris and Parc des Buttes-Chaumont, located at the four points of the compass around the city, as well as many smaller parks, squares and gardens in the <this city>'s quarters. Since 1977, the city has created 166 new parks, most notably the Parc de la Villette (1987), Parc André Citroën (1992), Parc de Bercy (1997) and Parc Clichy-Batignolles (2007). One of the newest parks, the Promenade des Berges de la Seine (2013), built on a former highway on the left bank of the Seine between the Pont de l'Alma and the Musée d'Orsay, has floating gardens.

Cemeteries
During the Roman era, the city's main cemetery was located to the outskirts of the left bank settlement, but this changed with the rise of Catholic Christianity, where most every inner-city church had adjoining burial grounds for use by their parishes. With <this city>'s growth many of these, particularly the city's largest cemetery, the Holy Innocents' Cemetery, were filled to overflowing. When inner-city burials were condemned from 1786, the contents of all <this city>'s parish cemeteries were transferred to a renovated section of <this city>'s stone mines, today place Denfert-Rochereau in the 14th arrondissement.After a tentative creation of several smaller suburban cemeteries, the Prefect Nicholas Frochot under Napoleon Bonaparte provided a more definitive solution in the creation of three massive <this city>ian cemeteries outside the city limits. Open from 1804, these were the cemeteries of Père Lachaise, Montmartre, Montparnasse, and later Passy. New suburban cemeteries were created in the early 20th century: The largest of these are the Cimetière parisien de Saint-Ouen, the Cimetière parisien de Pantin (also known as Cimetière parisien de Pantin-Bobigny), the Cimetière parisien d'Ivry, and the Cimetière parisien de Bagneux. Famous people buried in <this city>ian cemeteries include Oscar Wilde, Frédéric Chopin, Jim Morrison, Édith Piaf and Serge Gainsbourg.

Education
<this city> is the département with the highest proportion of highly educated people. In 2009, around 40 percent of <this city>ians held a licence-level diploma or higher, the highest proportion in <this country>, while 13 percent have no diploma, the third-lowest percentage in <this country>. Education in <this city> and the Île-de-<this country> region employs approximately 330,000 people, 170,000 of whom are teachers and professors teaching approximately 2.9 million students in around 9,000 primary, secondary, and higher education schools and institutions.The University of <this city>, founded in the 12th century, is often called the Sorbonne after one of its original medieval colleges. It was broken up into thirteen autonomous universities in 1970, following the student demonstrations in 1968. Most of the campuses today are in the Latin Quarter where the old university was located, while others are scattered around the city and the suburbs.The <this city> region hosts <this country>'s highest concentration of the grandes écoles – 55 specialised centres of higher-education outside or inside the public university structure. The prestigious public universities are usually considered grands établissements. Most of the grandes écoles were relocated to the suburbs of <this city> in the 1960s and 1970s, in new campuses much larger than the old campuses within the crowded City of <this city>, though the École Normale Supérieure, PSL University has remained on rue d'Ulm in the 5th arrondissement.

Healthcare
Health care and emergency medical service in the City of <this city> and its suburbs are provided by the Assistance publique – Hôpitaux de <this city> (AP-HP), a public hospital system that employs more than 90,000 people (including practitioners, support personnel, and administrators) in 44 hospitals. It is the largest hospital system in Europe. It provides health care, teaching, research, prevention, education and emergency medical service in 52 branches of medicine. The hospitals receive more than 5.8 million annual patient visits.One of the most notable hospitals is the Hôtel-Dieu, founded in 651, the oldest hospital in the city and the oldest worldwide still operating, although the current building is the product of a reconstruction of 1877. Other hospitals include Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital (one of the largest in Europe), Hôpital Cochin, Bichat–Claude Bernard Hospital, Hôpital Européen Georges-Pompidou, Bicêtre Hospital, Beaujon Hospital, the Curie Institute, Lariboisière Hospital, Necker–Enfants Malades Hospital, Hôpital Saint-Louis, Hôpital de la Charité and the American Hospital of <this city>.

International relations
International organisations
The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) has had its headquarters in <this city> since November 1958. <this city> is also the home of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). <this city> hosts the headquarters of the European Space Agency, the International Energy Agency, European Securities and Markets Authority and the European Banking Authority.

Twin towns – sister cities
Since 9 April 1956, <this city> is exclusively and reciprocally twinned with:
 Rome, 1956Seule <this city> est digne de Rome; seule Rome est digne de <this city>. (in French)
Solo Parigi è degna di Roma; solo Roma è degna di Parigi. (in Italian)
